page.title: 15ECOLOGY IN GRIMLEY
page.content: Surrounding the village of Grimley are several large ponds. Some have been formed from gravel excavations. Water seeking plants grow here and various water fowl can be seen. Swans nest on the ponds between the school and the River Severn. This area, the flood plain of the river, is marshy and left to grow naturally. Crack willows and other species of trees surround the school area. Hedge- rows are still in existence and give cover for wildlife and vegetation. Monkwood near Sinton Green is an ancient wood and a habitat for wild life. The trees are mainly deciduous. Many wild flowers grow here and sever- al species of butterflies can be seen. Pheasants wander about. There are many footpaths in the parish which give access to the river and the surrounding countryside.
